with Potent Antitumor Efficacy in HER2-Positive Breast Cancer 7633022 Auvert Etienne 7192348 Douez Emmanuel 7192352 Jolivet Louis 7633036 Witkowski Tiffany 7633040 Jallas Anne-Catherine 7192354 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8610-1122 Boursin Fanny 7633046 Molnar Ioana 4771960 https://orcid.org/0000-0003-1651-6813 Colas Cyril 7633054 Wittmann Sandrine Valsesia 7633059 Auriol Manon 5967300 Chezal Jean-Michel 7192359 Aubrey Nicolas 2435730 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6973-6812 Allard-Vannier Emilie 7633072 Maisonial-Besset Aurélie 3404940 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7335-4921 Joubert Nicolas 5643625 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9901-7608 Denevault-Sabourin Caroline  † UMR

of Organic and Analytical Chemistry, ICOA UMR 7311 CNRS University of Orléans F-45100 Orléans France * caroline.denevault@univ-tours.fr * nicolas.joubert@univ-tours.fr 05 9 2025 25 9 2025 68 18 497980 19122 19142 29 4 2025 08 8 2025 08 8 2025 05 9 2025 30 09 2025 01 10 2025 01 10 2025 © 2025 The Authors. Published by American Chemical Society 2025 The Authors https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This article is licensed under CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 The prognosis of
human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive
breast cancer has significantly improved with the advent of anti-HER2
therapies, especially antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs). In this field,
ADCs, like trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd), using camptothecin analogs,
represent a promising strategy. However, T-DXd can induce resistance
and serious adverse effects, potentially driven by a non-specific
Fcγ receptor-mediated endocytosis. Here, we report the development
of novel HER2-targeting conjugates, using the camptothecin derivative
exatecan and a linker optimized to control hydrophobicity. Three formats
were evaluated: a high drug-to-antibody ratio (DAR) 8 IgG-based ADC
(IgG(8)-EXA), and two DAR 4 Fc-free constructs (Mb(4)-EXA and Db(4)-EXA).
Thus, IgG(8)-EXA and Mb(4)-EXA displayed potent, specific cytotoxicity
against HER2-positive breast cancer cells and strong antitumor activity
in vivo . cancer worldwide. In 2022,
almost 2.31 million new cases and 666 000 deaths from this disease
were estimated globally by the International Agency for Research on
Cancer (IARC). HER2 HER2    ADCs are a combination of a potent small molecule
(also called
a drug or payload) chemically attached via a linker onto a monoclonal
antibody (mAb), used as a carrier, and allowing the selective delivery
of the drug into the tumor. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA)
approved two anti-HER2 ADCs, the trastuzumab emtansine (T-DM1) and,
more recently, the trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd). T-DM1 consists
of the linker emtansine (4- N    N p    However, T-DXd presents a toxicity profile close to
the one observed
with conventional chemotherapy, such as gastrointestinal and hematologic
adverse effects or alopecia. Approved therapeutic ADCs are constructed using a mAb
with an immunoglobulin
G (IgG) format. The IgG format possesses a fragment crystallizable
(Fc) domain, which has advantages but also drawbacks. Indeed, it can
bind to the neonatal Fc receptor (FcRn), increasing biological half-life
but also the exposure of healthy tissues. Moreover, this IgG1 isotype
can also engage FcγR via the Fc portion, which can be responsible
for secondary immune functions (antibody-dependent cell-mediated or
complement-dependent cytotoxicities) that can contribute to the mechanism
of action of the immunoconjugate. Nevertheless, as previously mentioned,
FcγR-mediated uptake of immunoconjugate by normal tissues can
also trigger off-target toxicity like thrombocytopenia. Exatecan is a camptothecin topoisomerase I
inhibitor closely related
to DXd.  12   We reported herein the
design, synthesis, characterization, and
biological evaluations of these new immunoconjugates. Results Design of Antibody
Formats and Drug Linkers In this
study, three immunoconjugates formed with different antibody formats,
targeting HER2, were compared to the marketed T-DXd and to a negative
control, a DAR 8 ADC, synthesized using a nonrelevant humanized IgG
(IgG irr H L 3 H L H L L H L The enzyme-cleavable drug-linker includes the Ala-Ala-PABC sequence,
a cathepsin B-sensitive trigger, where the PABC plays the role of
a self-immolative spacer to free the potent unmodified cytotoxic agent

the affinity of
an immunoconjugate is crucial for the selective targeting of tumor
cell-surface antigens, we further investigated the HER2 binding properties
of all immunoconjugates in comparison to their unconjugated native
antibody format using indirect enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).
No significant change in HER2 binding recognition was observed when
the antibody formats were entirely reduced and conjugated to drug-linker 12 Figure 12 3 HER2 binding recognition measured by indirect ELISA of: ( A 13 B 14 C 15 HER2-Mediated Endocytosis of Immunoconjugates An efficient
endocytosis within HER2-positive tumor cells is also an essential
step for the activity of such immunoconjugates, permitting the trafficking
into the lysosome, where the cathepsin B-catalyzed release of exatecan
can occur. The HER2-mediated internalization of all immunoconjugates
was therefore assessed by flow cytometry and fluorescence microscopy
experiments on a SK-BR-3 human breast cancer cell line, characterized
by HER2 (Neu/ErbB-2) gene amplification, leading to HER2 overexpression
at the cell membrane surface (HER2-positive). We first evaluated the
endocytosis by a semiquantitative method using flow cytometry, after
the preincubation of immunoconjugates with an intracellular tracer,
the protein L coupled to phycoerythrin (ppL-PE) ( Supporting Information Figure S9 Figure 13 15 irr 16 13 15 13 14 Figure 13 15 13 15 irr 16 4 Internalization of immunoconjugates in SK-BR-3 (HER2-positive)

( 13 14 Discussion and Conclusions In the field of ADCs development,
the design of third-generation
immunoconjugates bearing less cytotoxic payloads (like the two camptothecin
analogs DXd and SN-38) than those commonly used in first and second-generation
ADCs in clinic (i.e., microtubule inhibitors or DNA-damaging agents)
seems to be an emerging and promising strategy. This is reflected
by the approval in recent years of several ADCs containing camptothecin
analogs,  In addition, even if T-DXd represents a real breakthrough in the
treatment of HER2-positive solid tumors, it often induces severe side
effects and patients finally experience progression of disease, due
to acquired mechanisms of resistance.  12  Many studies
have shown that conjugation onto mAbs of nonoptimized
hydrophobic drug-linkers with high DAR increases the overall hydrophobicity
of the immunoconjugates produced, promoting aggregates, accelerated
plasma clearance, immunogenicity, off-target toxicity, and reduced
in vivo efficacy.     In this study, we developed a convergent and modular synthetic
route leading to the new exatecan-based drug-linker 12 9 The orthogonal lysine-(PEG) 12 12 12 Enzymatic studies after exposure
of immunoconjugate 14 Moreover, conjugation
of the drug-linker 12 12 In addition, for all anti-HER2
conjugates of this study, efficient
endocytosis within HER2-positive breast cancer cells was observed,
with a markedly improved internalization profile, in comparison to
T-DXd, especially for IgG(8)-EXA ( 13 14 12 Finally, the performance of these exatecan-based immunoconjugates
was confirmed with a specific, low nanomolar to subnanomolar cytotoxicity
(proportionally to the DAR) against HER2-positive cancer cells, for
the two most promising candidates, IgG(8)-EXA 13 14 13 l l Our previous studies related to immunoconjugates bearing
an orthogonal
lysine-(PEG) 12 C P C P 13 12 13 14 14  14 13 These promising results remain to be completed, particularly
with
further in vivo innocuity studies to confirm the therapeutic potential
of these two candidates. This drug-linker strategy could ultimately
be applied to different types of antibodies and antibody fragments
for applications in a large variety of tumors. Experimental
Section Protein Expression, Purification, and Characterization For the synthesis of IgG(8)-EXA ( 13 14 15 irr 16 Loxosceles intermedia GeneArt synthesized
the sequences of all antibody format constructs in pcDNA3.4 plasmids
(Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, USA). We designed the nucleotide
sequences with optimized codons from Cricetulus griseus 6 2 6 2 For the purification step, supernatants were deep-frozen, then
centrifuged at 10,000 g for 20 min, passed over a 220 nm filter, and
purified by affinity chromatography with a kta purifier (Cytiva Europe
GmbH, Velizy-Villacoublay, France, 17–5478–14). We purified
the various antibody formats using a HiScreen Capto L column (Cytiva
Europe GmbH, Velizy-Villacoublay, France, 17–5478–14)
in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (2.7 mM KCl, 0.10 M NaCl, 2 mM
KH 2 4 2 4 http://web.expasy.org/protparam/ We assessed the integrity
and size of all purified antibody formats
by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE),
on homogeneous 12% polyacrylamide gel, under reducing or nonreducing
conditions. We loaded all purified antibody format samples at 1 μg
for Coomassie Blue staining (0.1% Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250,
10% glacial acetic acid, and 30% methanol). Then, we resolved
the purified antibody formats preparations by
SEC-HPLC analysis, on a Superdex 200 10/300 GL column (molecular mass
range 10,000–200,000 Da) (GE Healthcare Life Sciences), with
an Äkta purifier. We loaded the column with 0.02 mg of each
antibody format. We eluted the proteins with PBS at a rate of 0.5
mL/min, and we detected them at 280 nm with a UV detector. Then,
we performed differential scanning fluorimetry experiments
on a nanoDSF device (Prometheus NT.48, NanoTemper) to determine the
thermal unfolding. We used all samples at a final concentration of
0.01 nM and loaded them into high-sensitivity capillaries. We subjected
the protein unfolding process to a thermal ramp (20 to 95 °C,
1 °C/min). We performed data analysis using the Prometheus PR
ThermControl software. We determined the thermal denaturation (Tm)
value by fitting the tryptophan 350/330 nm fluorescence emission ratio
using a polynomial function, in which the maximum slope was indicated
by the peak of its first derivative. Synthesis of Compounds We purchased all solvents as
anhydrous reagents from commercial sources. We obtained all of the
reagents and chemicals from commercial sources and used them without
purification (unless otherwise noted). Exatecan mesylate was purchased
from Advanced ChemBlocks Inc. (#10484). The 6-maleimidocaproic acid
was prepared according to literature procedures. We performed thin layer chromatography (TLC) using
commercial precoated aluminum sheets, silica gel (60 Å, F254;
Merk). We revealed them under a 254 nm UV lamp. We carried out column
chromatography on a Combi Flash RF 75 PSI, an ISCO purification unit,
using Redisep flash silica gel columns (60 Å, 230–400
mesh, grade 9385). We determined the purity of the compounds by high-performance
liquid chromatography (HPLC) or by ultra-performance liquid chromatography
(UPLC). We carried out HPLC analyses with a LaChrom Elite system [Hitachi
L-2130 (pump), L-2400 (UV-detector at 254 nm at 25 °C) and L-2200
(autosampler)], using a XBridge C-18 column (250 mm × 10 mm,
4 μm, 135 Å). We eluted with a flow rate of 1 mL/min, using
0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) in water (solvent A), and 0.1% TFA
in acetonitrile (MeCN) (solvent B), with a gradient over 35 min from
20% of B to 100% of B. We injected 10 μL of each sample at 1
mg/mL in DMSO. We carried out UPLC analyses using a Waters ACQUITY
UPLC H-Class system (UV-detector at 254 nm at 25 °C) equipped
with a Waters XBridge BEH C-18 column (100 mm × 2.1 mm, 2.5 μm,
130 Å). We eluted with a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min, using solvents
A and B (predefined for HPLC analysis), with a gradient from 5 to
100% B over 5 min. We injected 3 μL of each sample at 1 mg/mL
in DMSO. We purified the compounds by semipreparative HPLC according
to the following general method: we purified each crude product on
a Gilson PLC 2050 system [ARMEN V2 (pump), ECOM TOYDAD600 (UV-detector
at 254 nm at 25 °C)] equipped with a Waters XBridge C-18 column
(250 mm × 19 mm, 5 μm); we eluted with a flow rate of 17.1
mL/min, using solvents A and B (predefined for HPLC analysis) with
a gradient from 20 to 100% of B over 32 min and then 100% of B for
6 min. NMR spectra were recorded at 400 MHz ( 1 13 19 2 3  For small-molecule mass analysis,
we performed HRMS analysis with
an Acquity UPLC H-Class system, hyphenated to a mass spectrometer,
a Vion IMS Q-Tof instrument (Waters). Before MS analysis, we injected
1.0 ng of each sample onto a BEH C18 column (2.1 mm × 50 mm,
1.7 μm), which was heated to 50 °C. We eluted each sample
with a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min, using solvents A (H 2 m z Fmoc-Ala-Ala-O t To a solution

IgG (IgG irr 12 irr 12 17 Characterization of Immunoconjugates We analyzed immunoconjugates
by denaturing HRMS analysis on a Bruker maXis mass spectrometer coupled
to a Dionex Ultimate 3000 RSLC system. Prior to MS analysis, we desalted
each sample (ca. 5 μg) on a MassPREP desalting cartridge (2.1
× 10 mm, Waters), which was heated at 80 °C, using 0.1%
formic acid (solvent A) and 0.1% formic acid in MeCN (solvent B) at
a rate of 500 μL/min. After 1 min, we applied a linear gradient
from 5 to 90% B in 1.5 min, for which the first 1.5 min were diverted
to waste. We acquired HRMS data in positive mode with an ESI source,
over the m z average L H For the minibody format, we recorded the
results for the fragments V H L 3 average VHVL–CH 3 For the diabody format, we recorded the results for
fragments V H L average VHVL For SEC-HPLC analysis, we diluted each sample of
the immunoconjugate
to 1.0 mg/mL with PBS (pH 7.4) and filtered it on a 220 nm PVDF membrane.
We injected a sample of 40 μg on an AdvanceBio SEC instrument
(7.8 × 300 mm, 2.7 μm) from Agilent Technologies connected
to a Waters Alliance (e2695) apparatus, equipped with a photodiode
array detector (2998) set for detection at 280 nm. We eluted each
sample with an isocratic gradient (1.0 mM potassium phosphate monobasic,
3 mM sodium phosphate dibasic, 155 mM sodium chloride, and 3 mM sodium
azide, pH 7.0) over 24 min at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. We maintained
the column oven temperature at 25 °C. Cathepsin B Enzymatic Cleavage First, we realized the
cleavage of the Ala-Ala linker. The reactivity of the maleimide scaffold
of linker 12 10 10 The cleavage of the whole immunoconjugate was realized on immunoconjugate 14 14 HER2-Binding ELISA Assay We coated HER2 recombinant
protein (Sino Biologicals, Beijing, P. R. China) in 96-well plates
at 1.0 μg/mL in PBS and we incubated it overnight at 4 °C.
Then we saturated the wells with 3.0% bovine serum albumin (BSA)-PBS
at 37 °C for 1 h, and we washed with PBS, prior to incubation
with PBS (negative control), immunoconjugates, nonconjugated antibody
formats, or trastuzumab deruxtecan (Enhertu, Daiichi Sankyo, Japan)
from 0.001 to 1000 (or 100) nM at 37 °C during 1 h. Then, we
washed the wells with PBS-Tween 20 (0.05%) and incubated them with
100 μL of protein-L-peroxydase (ThermoScientific) at 1.25 μg/mL
at 37 °C for 1 h; then, we added 100 μL of 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine
(TMB) substrate (Sigma) in each well. Finally, we stopped the enzymatic
reaction with the addition of 50 μL of 1.0 M H 2 4 Cell Culture We obtained MDA-MB-468 human breast carcinoma
cells from the American Type Culture Collection (LGC Promochem). The
cells were cultured in Minimum Essential Medium (MEM) with GlutaMAX,
10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Gibco), sodium pyruvate (100 nM), AANE
1X (100X), vitamins 1X (100X), 1% penicillin-streptomycin solution
(10,000 U/mL, Gibco), and gentamycin (50 mg/mL, Gibco) at 37 °C
with 5% CO 2 2 2 Flow Cytometry Analysis
for Internalization We used
protein L coupled with phycoerythrin (ppL-PE, Sinobiological, Beijing,
China) as an intracellular tracer. Protein L was obtained from Peptostreptococcus magnus Fluorescence Microscopy
for Internalization We incubated
150,000 SK-BR-3 or MDA-MB-468 cells for 24 h on poly- d In Vitro Cytotoxicity Cell viability was studied using
the CellTiter-Glo cell proliferation assay (Promega, Wisconsin, USA),
by means of a luminescent test based on ATP quantification. Briefly,
we incubated 3000 MDA-MB-468 cells or 6,000 SK-BR-3 cells in 100 μL
of medium in 96-well plates for 24 h. Then we treated them with concentrations
ranging from 0.001 to 1000 nM of the tested compounds. We incubated
cells with 100 μL of each compound with 5% CO 2 2 2 50 n Serum Stability Analysis Immunoconjugate samples were
prepared in IgG-depleted human serum or mouse serum at 50% serum content
and a 0.5 mg/mL immunoconjugate concentration. Immunoconjugates were
assessed for stability over a 192 h time course at 37 °C with
samples taken for analysis at 24, 48, 72, 96, and 192 h and frozen
at −80 °C until analysis. Samples were assessed by affinity
capture and LC-MS analysis for the average DAR assessment. Affinity
capture of the serum stability samples was carried out using Cytiva
protein A magnetic beads (Cytiva Cat. 28944006) by incubating with
serum samples for 1 h at rt with constant mixing. The beads were washed
thoroughly with wash buffer before the elution of immunoconjugate
samples from the beads with 2 mM HCl. The acidic eluent was neutralized
with 100 mM TRIS buffer, pH 8.0. Eluents were reduced by adding 200
mM final DTT and analyzed by LC-MS on a Waters H Class Acquity in
line with a Waters RDa TOF (Waters Bioaccord). The chromatographic
separation was performed by denaturing SEC (dSEC) on a Waters Acquity
UPLC Protein BEH SEC, 200 Å, 1.7 μm, 4.6 mm × 300
mm column. The elution was performed under isocratic conditions at
0.3 mL/min with 0.1% formic acid and 30% Acetonitrile in water as
the mobile phase. The MS analysis was performed in positive polarity
under continuous scanning at 400–7000 m z In Vivo Tumor Model All animal experiments were performed
in accordance with the European directive 2010/63/EU following the
protocols evaluated and approved by the governmental committee APAFiS
(Ethics Approval Number: #39465–2022111811066226 v5). Seven
(biodistribution study) or six (therapeutic efficacy study) weeks
old SCID CB17 female mice (Charles River Laboratories, Domaine des
Oncins, L’abresle, France) were housed in standard conditions
(4 to 6 animals per cage, on ventilated racks, 60% humidity, temperature
21–24 °C, 12/12 h light/dark cycle, with free access to
standard food and water). A total of 5 million BT-474-SCID cells were
injected subcutaneously (s.c.) in the flank after gaseous anesthesia
(Isoflurane, Iso-Vet, 1.5%, 1 L/min, air/O 2  L * l 2 2 L l L Radiolabeling with Iodine-125 General We purchased [ 125 –5 –1 Radiolabeling with Iodine-125 We radiolabeled antibodies

we observed and weighed mice
to evaluate the general clinical state and detect end points. We calculated

were sacrificed 63 days after cell inoculation (corresponding
to 32 days post treatment) by gaseous anesthesia, followed by cervical
dislocation. Statistical Analysis Body weight
evolution was analyzed
by multiple comparisons with a two-way ANOVA test. TV evolution was
analyzed by a linear mixed model with mixed effects for treatment,
time, and interaction. Random effect was used to analyze and integrate
individual variations. Posthoc comparison (paired comparison) was
used on the mixed model with a Benjamini-Hochberg multiple test correction
in order to study the post-treatment period and adjust p Supplementary Material The authors
